body_html:
It has been a while since I revisited cifar10 training in fp16.
I recently tried cifar10 training with --use_fp16 with a P100 using TF 1.4 and the perf is really bad compared to fp32.
Some observations:

  1. On my P100 fp32 trains at ~16000 examples/sec, while using --use_fp16 it drops down to ~780 examples/sec
  2. I notice that for fp16 the GPU is highly underutilized ... just about 4% (as seen with nvidia-smi) and the CPU cores are pretty busy at ~80%. - so it seems like most ops are being done on the CPU.
  3. For fp32 training the CPU is about 30% busy and the GPU varies between 80 and 100%

Anyone else have better luck with this?

On my P100 fp32 trains at ~16000 examples/sec, while using --use_fp16 it drops down to ~780 examples/sec
I notice that for fp16 the GPU is highly underutilized ... just about 4% (as seen with nvidia-smi) and the CPU cores are pretty busy at ~80%. - so it seems like most ops are being done on the CPU.
For fp32 training the CPU is about 30% busy and the GPU varies between 80 and 100%

Anyone else have better luck with this?
body:
It has been a while since I revisited cifar10 training in fp16.  
I recently tried cifar10 training with --use_fp16 with a P100 using TF 1.4 and the perf is really bad compared to fp32.  
Some observations:

1. On my P100 fp32 trains at ~16000 examples/sec, while using --use_fp16 it drops down to ~780 examples/sec
2. I notice that for fp16 the GPU is highly underutilized ... just about 4% (as seen with nvidia-smi) and the CPU cores are pretty busy at ~80%. - so it seems like most ops are being done on the CPU.  
3. For fp32 training the CPU is about 30% busy and the GPU varies between 80 and 100%

Anyone else have better luck with this?
